title: Who Am I, Again? by Lenny Henry review – a cry of existential angst
text:
“Lenny Henry owes me an apology,’’ said a black friend recently. “For all those years when he told unfunny jokes against black people on TV, Lenny owes me.”

But, focusing on the first decade of his career, Henry argues in his memoir, Who Am I, Again?, that for a black performer to survive in the world of 1970s light entertainment it was best “to get all the dodgy jokes in before [the audience] did”.

My Jamaican family always considered him a candidate for compassion, for it seemed obvious that his youth and talent were being exploited. For decades, the buffoonery of black TV personalities – from Ainsley Harriott to Frank Bruno – was encouraged and expected by white producers. Pandering to British bigotry appeared a prerequisite for employment.

Henry’s breakthrough came as a teenager on the television talent contest New Faces. With his back to the audience, in that first dramatic appearance, he gave a passable impersonation of Frank Spencer (a much-mimicked TV character), but audiences were both aghast and thrilled when Henry turned round to reveal that he was black.

A year later, aged 17, Henry was assured by Robert Luff, the entrepreneur and impresario, that his next step, appearing on The Black and White Minstrel Show, would prove his making. Henry doesn’t shy away from this problematic stage of his career. For five years, he toured with the long-legged dance troupe the Television Toppers and their blacked-up partners, performing Al Jolson melodies; they were also a recurring delight for millions of Saturday evening viewers on British TV.

Looking back now, Henry detects a degree of cynicism on Luff’s part, for when the minstrel act was criticised, “His staff could point at me and say: ‘How can we be racist? Look – we’ve got Lenny Henry in the show.’”

The experience left Henry with a “palette of conflicting emotions”. Born in Dudley to Jamaican parents, with a mother who was especially determined to assimilate, Henry now discerns in her the roots of his inversion of Malcolm X’s maxim: “Perhaps one of the products of [mum’s] H’Integration Project was that I was... told to fit in by any means necessary.”

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Henry in his home town, Dudley, November 1978. Photograph: Mirrorpix/Getty Images

He paints a sad picture of a confused man-boy. Through much of his early career he was an invisible man, a mimic with a chameleon-like personality, and unknowable to himself. Appearing at tough working men’s clubs, he confesses now to being schooled in a comedy vocabulary targeting “thick Irishmen”, “lascivious blacks” and “randy housewives” that was soon outmoded and no longer fit for purpose.

As the title suggests, the memoir is a cry of existential angst. “Beginning to think,” wrote Albert Camus, “is beginning to be undermined.” Henry took safety in not thinking, and he wrestles in the book with the lessons he might have learned, or hopes to impart. Nonetheless, in charting the popularity of the often cruel, cliched comedy of the period, Henry has written a painfully honest account of his ascendancy in British culture. Along the way the memoir offers insights into the one step forwards, two steps backwards evolution of racial enlightenment in the UK, evident in the excrement smeared on his front door in protest against his association with a white woman (Dawn French).

The opening lyrical passages of Who Am I, Again? soon default to a checklist of familiar adolescent concerns: he’s thrilled to be considered friend material for an older white youth who drives a car; he styles himself in a Freeman’s catalogue jacket; and the bedroom mirror tells him the obvious truth – that he’s “cooler than cold”.

There are more rewarding moments when Henry breaks away from the text to render anecdotes in graphic novel form, poignantly yet humorously so in the revelation that the man he knew as “Uncle Bertie” was in fact his biological father.

No amount of comedy, though, can shake the conviction that Henry is stalked by his association with the minstrelsy of his youth. Creative liberty from that show, and from his adoption of one-liner jokes (“laughter delivery mechanisms”), came courtesy of Tiswas, the zany Saturday morning children’s TV programme – with its caged celebrities, buckets of water, custard pies, and, arguably one of Henry’s most inventive characters, the pretentious Rastafarian, Algernon Winston Spencer Churchill Gladstone Disraeli Palmerston Pitt the Younger Pitt the Elder Razzmatazz. He makes the bold assertion that Tiswas was part of the zeitgeist, ushering in alternative “anarchic, left-leaning performers”. But what is remarkable about Henry has been his determination to steer a path away from his unfortunate past, to the restoration of a truer, more admirable self.

Last year, at the Stephen Lawrence Memorial Lecture, Sir Lenny stood in front of assembled dignitaries and lambasted the government for its shameful treatment of his parents’ peers (the Windrush generation) in its hostile environment policy.

Following on from that speech, this memoir is a heartfelt atonement for the rewards of the prejudiced times that have led us to the mess we’re in; and a reminder of who he really is, again. Increasingly, in answering racists and racist ideology, Henry has heeded the advice of his former colleague Victoria Wood: “Whatever they say, just say something back.”

Colin Grant’s Homecoming: Voices of the Windrush Generation is published by Vintage (£18.99)
